Altering your practice’s approach for COVID-19

COVID-19 has made it more challenging in the healthcare industry. Many practices that primarily offer elective or non-emergency services are finding it more challenging to acquire new patients. Healthcare practices that deal directly with the diagnosis and treatment of COVID-19 find themselves more vulnerable and must take more precautions when dealing with patients.

Regardless, every practice is affected in one way or another. Thus, practices must temporarily alter their approach to be more accommodating to the needs of patients and staff during the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Digital marketing strategies to recover from COVID-19

One way to minimize the financial impact COVID-19 has on your practice and recover faster is through implementing digital marketing tools and strategies. Offline marketing such as billboard advertisements, medical conferences, etc. are not as effective because more are staying home for social distancing purposes. However, the use of digital devices is likely to increase. This increase in usage means practices need to alter their methods for reaching patients to help stay afloat.

As for COVID-19, we seek to assist healthcare practices by offering informational resources, particularly content that deals with managing their practice during social distancing and continuing to acquire new patients during the fight to reduce the spread.

prevPost.content:
If you strive to improve your practice, a Kaizen action plan is a must. This action plan will allow you to make small changes that create continuous improvement for employees, patients, and the practice as a whole. These changes are small but can make a huge impact on your practice’s processes and functions. For this to work, you need to develop and use an action plan.

Plan, do, check and act with a Kaizen action plan

Many practices like the idea of the Kaizen philosophy but do not understand how to implement it. Successful practices often pair the PDCA cycle (plan, do check and act) with the Kaizen philosophy to get results. The two strategies support one another and allow practices to make small, measurable, and sustainable improvements. Also, this strategy involves employees, increasing engagement throughout the practice.

The “Plan” stage

A Kaizen action plan should begin with the “plan” stage. Just as it sounds, practices must plan the strategy before moving to the next step. During the stage, employees identify a problem. For instance, the problem could be something as simple as long wait times. After the problem is determined, the practice must gather data related to it.

Then, the practice must find a solution to the problem. The solution might be avoiding double-booking patients or changing a policy about seeing late patients. Involved parties need to consider the possible outcomes of implementing the solution, as well as a method for measuring its success. All changes must be measurable for the action plan to work.

The “do” stage

During the “do” stage, the practice implements the plan. Someone needs to be in charge of collecting data when implementing the plan. The data should clearly show if the plan helps the practice. All data is carried over to the next stage when the practice determines if the plan is viable.

The “check” stage

Team members should analyze the data during the “check” stage to see if the plan worked as expected. Did it generate the anticipated results? Did the plan help the practice? Is the solution practical and helpful instead of disruptive? Practices need to ask these questions to determine how effective the plan was.

The “act” stage

The “act” stage is the last part of the action plan. If the plan worked, the practice needs to announce the change to all employees. It is also essential to add any changes to practice training materials and handbooks. If it did not work, the practice needs to start the process once again. Some changes do not work, but if practices go back to the drawing board, they will find a solution to the problem.

Make positive changes with Kaizen

A Kaizen action plan will help you make positive changes for your practice. Train your employees on this strategy and have everyone take part in developing a plan. When you open your practice up to suggestions, you can make important changes that improve satisfaction for employees and patients. This will help you retain employees and patients and allow your practice to generate more revenue.

nextPost.title: Mental, Physical and Emotional Support Resources for Medical Teams
nextPost.excerpt: Medical teams are more vulnerable during the COVID-19 pandemic. This increased risk can make it mentally, physically, and emotionally taxing [ More.. ]
nextPost.content:
Medical teams are more vulnerable during the COVID-19 pandemic. This increased risk can make it mentally, physically, and emotionally taxing on healthcare workers as they treat patients. Fortunately, there are support resources available to help those who may find their job to be more demanding than usual.

The Importance of support for medical teams

All too often, the health and well-being of medical teams get overlooked during times of crisis. The jobs of medical professionals are far more challenging because they often treat patients who may have contagious conditions such as COVID-19. For many, this causes increased anxiety and distress, which can affect short-term and long-term well-being.

It is crucial for medical teams to have support resources available to them, so they can deal with any negative mental, physical, or emotional concerns they have. Many medical workers begin to feel more anxious, experience extreme fatigue, and become more fearful as they treat patients who may have COVID-19. Support resources help them deal with these concerns and be at their healthiest mental and physical state so they can do their jobs to the best of their ability. 

Resources for mental, physical and emotional support

There are many support resources available to medical teams. In addition to seeking assistance from others within the practice, workers can find support from the following resources:

American Psychiatric Association (APA): The APA offers well-being resources for healthcare workers who may experience burnout, anxiety, depression, and more.

American Medical Association (AMA): The AMA has special resources designed for medical workers to take care of themselves, as well as insights into how practices can provide assistance for their staff.

World Health Organization (WHO): Resources such as WHO and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) are a great place to learn more about COVID-19. 

Health Care Toolbox: The Health Care Toolbox offers resources for medical professionals who deal with COVID-19.

Headspace: Headspace is a unique app that allows medical workers to de-stress after a long day and get a better night’s sleep.

Every medical worker should look out for their health and well-being as we fight COVID-19. Practices should also ensure that their staff has all the resources they need to cope mentally and physically during this time.

Tips for medical workers on coping with COVID-19

Most importantly, medical workers should take a moment each day to evaluate their mental and physical state. Putting coping strategies into place, such as eating healthy, staying active, and interacting with loved ones, can help workers deal with the challenge COVID-19 poses. It is essential to communicate with others within your medical team, especially those in a position of leadership if you are feeling mentally or physically overwhelmed.
